definitions: strike someone or something with the palm of your hand or a flat object
put or place something somewhere quickly and forcefully without much care
examples: She slapped the mosquito on her arm quickly
The angry customer slapped the table in frustration
He slapped the paint onto the wall carelessly
She slapped the sticker on her laptop case

definitions: move troops or equipment into position for military action or strategic purposes
bring into effective action or use a resource, skill, or quality strategically
examples: The army will deploy soldiers to the border region
The company deployed security guards around the building perimeter
The manager deployed her team's skills to complete the project
We need to deploy our resources more efficiently this quarter

definitions: have someone as the main performer or most important person in a show or event
mark or decorate something with star symbols or give a star rating
examples: The new movie stars several famous Hollywood actors together
She will star in the upcoming Broadway musical production
The teacher starred the best answers on the test
Hotels are starred according to their quality and service

definitions: press or squeeze something so hard that it breaks, becomes damaged, or changes shape
defeat someone or something completely and overwhelmingly in competition or conflict
have a brief but intense romantic attraction to someone, typically when young
examples: The machine crushes aluminum cans for recycling purposes daily
Don't crush the flowers when you pack them carefully
The home team crushed their rivals with impressive skill
The government crushed the rebellion within days of starting
She has a crush on her chemistry lab partner
He developed a crush on the new student immediately

definitions: regard or consider something in a specified way, often in formal or official contexts
examples: The court deemed the evidence insufficient for a conviction
The committee deemed her qualified for the prestigious position

definitions: cause water or another liquid to run out from something by removing a plug or opening
deplete someone or something of strength, energy, resources, or emotional reserves gradually
examples: Please drain the pasta before adding the sauce mixture
The plumber will drain the pipes before winter arrives
The long project drained all our financial resources completely
Constant stress can drain your energy and motivation quickly

definitions: be carried slowly by a current of air or water without control
gradually depart from an intended course, subject, or state without realizing it
examples: The boat drifted downstream with the gentle river current
Clouds drift across the sky on lazy summer afternoons
The conversation drifted from work topics to personal matters
They drifted apart after graduating from college together

definitions: lose blood from the body as a result of injury or illness
gradually spread from one area into another, especially of colors or substances
examples: The cut on his finger continued to bleed heavily
Her nose bleeds when the air becomes too dry
The red ink bled into the white fabric unfortunately
The colors bleed together when the painting gets wet

definitions: cause someone to feel surprised and upset by something unexpected or unpleasant
cause physical or psychological trauma through sudden impact or distressing experience
examples: The sudden news shocked everyone in the quiet room
His rude behavior shocked the dinner party guests completely
The accident shocked him into changing his driving habits
The electric fence shocks anyone who touches it accidentally

definitions: make secret or new information known publicly or to specific people formally
examples: The company must disclose its financial records to shareholders
She refused to disclose the source of her information

definitions: laugh quietly or inwardly with amusement or mild satisfaction about something
examples: He chuckled at the funny comic strip quietly to himself
She couldn't help but chuckle at the child's innocent question

definitions: force liquid, gas, or air to move somewhere using mechanical action or pressure
try persistently to obtain information from someone through repeated questioning
examples: The machine pumps water from the well every morning
You need to pump air into those flat bicycle tires
The detective pumped the witness for more details persistently
She pumped him for information about the surprise party

definitions: restore something damaged, broken, or faulty to good condition through fixing or mending
examples: The mechanic will repair your car engine by tomorrow
She learned how to repair her own computer at home

definitions: cause pain, distress, or difficulty to become less severe or serious for someone
take over duties or responsibilities from someone else to give them rest
examples: This medicine should relieve your headache within twenty minutes
A hot bath can relieve muscle tension after exercise
The night nurse will relieve you at eight o'clock
Fresh troops arrived to relieve the exhausted soldiers immediately

definitions: search or rummage through something thoroughly and untidily looking for something specific
establish something deeply and firmly in a particular place or situation
support or cheer enthusiastically for a person, team, or cause
examples: She rooted through her bag looking for car keys
The dog rooted around in the garbage can messily
These traditions are rooted in ancient cultural practices deeply
Fear of failure is rooted in childhood experiences often
The crowd rooted for their home team loudly all game
We're rooting for you to win the competition tomorrow

definitions: push, fold, or turn edges or ends of something into a particular place or position
make someone comfortable in bed by pulling covers up around them snugly
examples: She tucked her shirt into her skirt before leaving
He tucked the letter inside his jacket pocket secretly
The mother tucked her children into bed every night
She tucked the blanket around the sleeping baby gently

definitions: reduce something to the smallest possible amount, extent, size, or degree deliberately
examples: We need to minimize costs while maintaining quality standards
She tried to minimize the damage from her mistake

definitions: jump or spring a long way with great force from one place to another
increase, develop, or change suddenly and dramatically to a different level or state
examples: The athlete leaped over the high jump bar gracefully
The cat leaped from the tree to the roof
Sales leaped by fifty percent after the advertising campaign
She leaped at the chance to study abroad immediately

definitions: write a preliminary version of a document, plan, or drawing for later revision
select someone for compulsory military service or for a sports team officially
examples: She will draft the contract for the client meeting tomorrow
The author drafted three chapters of her new novel
The army drafted young men during the war years
The team drafted two new players this season successfully

definitions: supervise a person, task, or process to ensure everything is done correctly and efficiently
examples: The project manager will oversee all construction work carefully
She was hired to oversee the company's expansion plans

definitions: take property unlawfully from a person or place by force or threat of force
examples: The thieves robbed the bank during broad daylight yesterday
Someone robbed him of his wallet at the station

definitions: push someone or something roughly and suddenly with considerable force or violence
examples: Don't shove people when boarding the crowded subway train
He shoved the heavy box across the warehouse floor

definitions: begin again or continue after a pause, interruption, or period of inactivity
examples: We will resume the meeting after the lunch break
She resumed her studies after taking a year off

definitions: settle a dispute by mutual concession where each side makes some sacrifices
expose something to risk, suspicion, or danger by weakening its integrity or security
examples: Both parties agreed to compromise on the contract terms
They compromised by choosing a restaurant they both enjoyed
The leak compromised the security of the entire network
Don't compromise your values for temporary gains or benefits

definitions: arrange things systematically in groups according to type, size, or other criteria
resolve a problem, difficulty, or disagreement through careful action or discussion
examples: Please sort these files by date before filing them
The machine sorts packages by size and weight automatically
We need to sort out this misunderstanding before proceeding
She sorted the issue with her bank account yesterday

definitions: place, fit, or push something into something else, especially into a space or opening
examples: Insert the key into the lock and turn clockwise
The surgeon will insert a small tube during the procedure

definitions: struggle or compete vigorously with others to achieve or win something important
assert something as a position in an argument or state something is true
examples: Several companies contend for the government contract worth millions
The athletes contend for the gold medal every four years
The lawyer contends that her client is completely innocent
Scientists contend this theory explains the phenomenon better overall

definitions: provide lodging, space, or room for someone or something to stay or fit
adapt or adjust willingly to suit someone's needs, wishes, or particular circumstances
examples: The hotel can accommodate up to two hundred guests comfortably
This parking lot accommodates fifty cars when full completely
The teacher accommodates students with different learning styles effectively
We'll accommodate your schedule for the important meeting tomorrow

definitions: consist of or be made up of multiple parts, elements, or members collectively
examples: The committee comprises experts from various fields of study
The course comprises ten modules over six months total

definitions: work jointly with others toward a common goal or purpose through mutual assistance
examples: The two companies cooperate on several research projects annually
Students must cooperate to complete the group assignment successfully

definitions: pause before saying or doing something due to uncertainty, nervousness, or reluctance
examples: She hesitated before answering the difficult personal question honestly
Don't hesitate to call if you need any help

definitions: cause someone to feel upset, annoyed, or resentful by something said or done
commit an illegal act or break a law, rule, or accepted standard
examples: His careless remarks offended many people at the gathering
I didn't mean to offend you with my honest opinion
Those who offend repeatedly face harsher penalties under law
He was arrested for offending against public decency laws

definitions: use someone or something unfairly for your own advantage or benefit selfishly
make full use of and derive benefit from a resource or opportunity
examples: The company exploits workers by paying extremely low wages
Some people exploit their friends' generosity without reciprocating ever
Scientists exploit new technology to advance medical research significantly
The team exploited their opponent's weakness to win decisively

definitions: force or oblige someone to do something through pressure, circumstances, or overwhelming argument
examples: The court can compel witnesses to testify under oath
His passion for justice compelled him to speak out

definitions: commit oneself to begin and take responsibility for a task, project, or enterprise
examples: She will undertake the challenging research project next month
The company undertakes to deliver goods within five days

definitions: react with extreme or irrational emotion, especially fear, panic, or anger suddenly
behave or cause to behave in a wild, excited, and uncontrolled way
examples: She freaked out when she saw the spider move
Don't freak about the test results before studying properly
The loud noise freaked the horses in the stable
The unexpected news freaked everyone at the quiet office

definitions: come or bring to an end completely and permanently, especially in formal contexts
examples: The factory will cease operations at the month's end
They must cease all illegal activities immediately by law

definitions: disappear suddenly and completely from sight or existence without leaving a trace
examples: The magician made the rabbit vanish before our eyes
My keys seem to vanish whenever I need them most

definitions: work as a fashion model displaying clothes or products for photography or audiences
create a representation or simulation of something to show how it works
examples: She models designer clothing for major fashion magazines internationally
He models sportswear in television commercials every summer season
Scientists model climate change using advanced computer programs carefully
The architect modeled the building in 3D software first

definitions: give official permission or approval for something to happen or someone to act
examples: The manager must authorize all purchases over one thousand dollars
The board authorized the expansion of company operations overseas

definitions: form or devise a plan or idea in the mind through imagination or creative thinking
become pregnant with a child through biological reproduction
examples: She conceived a brilliant plan to solve the problem
It's hard to conceive how ancient civilizations built pyramids
The couple conceived their first child after two years
Many women conceive naturally without medical intervention or assistance

definitions: make a choice or decision from a range of possibilities after careful consideration
examples: Many students opt to study abroad during college years
She opted for the healthier menu option at lunch

definitions: move or fall downward through space, down stairs, or down a slope gradually
be related by genetic, cultural, or historical connection to an ancestor or source
examples: The hikers descended the mountain before sunset arrived quickly
The elevator descends to the basement parking level smoothly
She descends from a long line of talented musicians
Many English words descend from Latin and Greek origins

definitions: originate, arise, or be caused by a particular source or root cause
stop or restrict the flow or progress of something undesirable from spreading
examples: Most of his problems stem from poor financial planning
This tradition stems from ancient religious practices and beliefs
We must stem the tide of illegal drug trafficking
The nurse worked to stem the bleeding from the wound

definitions: deliver a sermon or religious address to an assembled group about moral topics
earnestly advocate or promote a belief, opinion, or course of action to others
examples: The minister preaches every Sunday morning at ten o'clock
She preached about forgiveness and compassion to the congregation
Don't preach to me about healthy eating habits constantly
He preaches the importance of education wherever he travels

definitions: intervene in a situation without invitation or necessity, often causing problems or delays
examples: Please don't interfere while I'm trying to concentrate here
Parents shouldn't interfere in their adult children's relationships constantly

definitions: examine and record the features or opinions of a group, area, or situation comprehensively
examine and measure land or buildings to create maps or establish boundaries
examples: Researchers survey public opinion before every major election cycle
She surveyed the damage caused by the storm yesterday
Engineers survey the land before beginning any construction project
They hired someone to survey their property boundaries accurately

definitions: put or arrange someone or something in a particular place or way strategically
examples: Position the camera to capture the best lighting angle
The coach positioned players strategically on the field yesterday

definitions: give or make available something extra that is not immediately needed to someone
refrain from killing, harming, or destroying someone or something as an act of mercy
examples: Can you spare some change for the parking meter
I can spare an hour to help you move
The judge spared him from the maximum prison sentence
Please spare the trees when clearing the land area

definitions: make or become less in size, importance, or intensity over a period of time
examples: Time doesn't diminish the pain of losing loved ones
Poor maintenance will diminish the value of your property
